Hey, I'm a high energy physicist who swung by and noticed your calculation of 4 kg as additional weight if you were made up of muonic atoms instead of traditional atoms. If we assume there are 1e28 electrons in the body, and 2e28 nucleons your mass would be around 32 kg. Plug in muons instead of electrons and you get ~34 kg. So you'd be about 2 kg heavier from just the mass of the muons alone, but you'd also be significantly denser, since the radial orbit of the muon in muonic atoms is ~200 times smaller than that of an electron. And ever more than that, much of our mass is generated by binding energies of molecules, and since the binding energy of muonic hydrogen is 200 times larger than the normal binding energy, I suspect you'd quickly surpass the additional 2 kg needed to make a 4 kg difference in the mass. To do a back of the envelope calculation, let's consider the molecule O2 which has a mass of 32 amu or 5.31e-26 kg, meaning there is an additional binding energy mass of ~ 2e-29 kg, or ~ 1.2e-28 kg per electron. If we then take this additional mass per electron from binding energies our normal mass comes out to 33 kg, but if we replace that with a factor of 207 from muon binding energies being so much greater you'd likely end up being 280 kg, and you'd be quite a bit smaller. Let me know if you object to my calculation, but I stand by the mass being significantly larger than a 4 kg difference, and it could be as large as 280 kg.

The Superconducting Super Collider that was being built in Texas near Waxahachie was going to research particle physics to find the answers to many of these questions. Unfortunately it was canceled by the Clinton administration. I worked there for three years in Project Management. My role was in the Magnet Division. We were responsible for building the huge magnets that would guide the particle beams around the 58 mile ring three hundred feet underground. I gathered data in many status meetings of different groups of scientists in order to incorporate their progress and problems into the master schedule. It was amazing to see these scientists from countries around the world, Poland, India, Italy, England, Russia, Germany etc. work together to build this colossus. Often at these meetings solutions to problems emerged because their varying backgrounds brought different insights to problem solving that none might have achieved on their own. I was so proud of the work they accomplished and so devastated when the project was canceled. On the day the project was cancelled I was at lunch at a small diner near the Magnet Test Laboratory. The diner was full of lab workers commiserating as we knew the project was gong to be canceled but were awaiting the final fall of the sword. We saw the announcement on a small TV in the diner. Soon there were reporters interviewing us about our reactions. I said some words to one of them along the lines of what I have written here. Later that evening at home having dinner I got a call from my youngest daughter Stacey, who lived in Annapolis Maryland. She shouted at me "Daddy, I saw you on national television". My three minutes of fame.

To this day I believe that the cancellation of the project was a blunder of colossal proportions. We had a gathering of some of the best minds in Physics from around the world. They were learning to coordinate and collaborate at a furious pace. I would not be surprised, if the project had been continued, that we might now have cold fusion or other mystical forms of energy in our lives. What a shame that we are now relegated to using windmills and sheets of glass to provide us energy. At this point I see that I've not mentioned the engineers who put the ideas of the physicists into reality. They were coming up with new ways to build this giant machine that were generating more patents than I could count.

As I reread what I've written so far I just let out a heavy sigh and feel so sad that we let politics prevent us from accomplishing what could have been a watershed moment in the development of our country. Oh, if I recall correctly, our Estimated Cost To Complete at the time of cancellation was 9.6 Billion. Also at that time 20% of the tunnel had been dug. The Linear Accelerator was up and running and we had just passed the Acceptance Test of the Magnet Test Facility that was capable of testing ten magnets at a time. This was important as the test facility had to re-liquefy helium and nitrogen gas to run through the magnets. No small feat. The test lab was a jungle of doubled walled vacuum sealed stainless steel piping. When you pump and control the flow of liquid gas that's -450 degrees, you have to know what you're doing.

OK, enough. Time for a taste of that magic elixir, Gunpowder gin.

Its really quite simple really. There is a single fundamental "field" wherein all possible field expressions can manifest through causality. Every "particle" is nothing more than a modality of the primordial field. That field is the dielectric field. Every possible "particle" can be discovered by 4 properties of the field's expressions:

1.) Permittivity
2.) Permeability
3.) Resistance
4.) Capacitance

Every particle "field" that is part of Quantum field theory are merely conglomerate amalgamations of the degrees of difference in the above 4 properties when expressed through a causal mechanism.

When academia stops worrying about new particles and starts really deep-diving into fundamental field theory, we will progress more in the next 10 years than in the past century.

The student of physics can write how photons made the entire universe in FIVE LINES of script!
Background: My suggestion is that soon after the Big Bang
Photons produced electron and positron pairs of waves

1. The ELECTRON wave had a negative charge.

2. The POSITRON wave had a positive charge.

3. The NEUTRINO had an electron and positron wave combined and had a neutral charge.

4. The PROTON had a mix of two positrons and one electron combined and had an overall positive charge.

5. The NEUTRON had a mix of two positrons and two electrons combined and had an overall neutral charge.

Therefore :

Photons made pairs of electrons and positrons.

The electrons and positrons mixed together to make neutrinos, protons and neutrons such that:

Electron (-)
Positron (+)
Neutrino (-) (+)
Proton (+) (-) (+)
Neutron (+) (-) (+) (-)

When this production of particles was over, most positrons (anti electrons), didn't exist on their own. They were locked into neutrinos, protons, and neutrons - though conservation of charge was maintained.
This may help explain the missing anti matter problem.

This period of the Big Bang was probably during the lepton epoch.

Though the neutrino and proton are extremely stable. the neutron can be converted back to a proton and electron (with an antineutrino) in beta decay.
Protons and electrons can convert to neutrons in neutron stars.
So proton + electron = neutrons has already been proven.

0:35 Gravity isn’t actually a force, as understood by Einstein and GR. Gravity is an interaction between two masses curving the space around them.

The easiest way to understand it is as Einstein explained it. An object in free fall does not experience (feel) acceleration. So a skydiver is free falling towards Earth, just as Earth is free falling towards the skydiver. Both objects are moving towards one another, however neither are accelerating in their own frame of reference, rather it is the other object seemingly accelerating towards it. So the skydiver would perceive the Earth accelerating towards him. And we standing on earth (feeling weight) are part of the planets frame of reference, so we observe the skydiver accelerating towards the planet.

Neither are actually accelerating, but both are changing their reference points towards one another as a seemingly accelerating rate.

I think there is a major aspect missing in this video. Even if the measurement is not a fluctuation, even if our theories are right, this measurement does not necessarily mean we are seeing signs of undiscovered forces or particles. Making the g-2 theoretical prediction is a very very complicated procedure. There is a lot of room for there to be mistakes or unrecognized imprecisions in the process. So the number we compare the experimental result to is about as likely to be the source of the discrepancy as the measurement itself is. It's certainly an intriguing outcome, and either way we will probably make progress - either by discovering something new, or by improving our ability to make precise predictions based on our theories. But I wouldn't place my bets on this being an actual sign of new physics just yet. Also, there is a good reason why we apply a 5 sigma threshold. Statements like "there is only a 1 in 40,000 chance this is a statistical fluctuation" sound like it is almost certainly not. But you need to take into account that we make many many measurements of various quantities. And if we measure many thousands of parameters, then a couple of them are bound to fluctuate as far out as this one. It's perfectly normal. Of course only the large fluctations get discussed in public, but you won't be surprised to hear that we have thousands of measurements that are not deviating from the Standard Model this much.

In other words I guess you could say the muons reaching farther down than expected is like Einstein’s thought experiment of a stationary vs a moving clock to represent the discrepancy between different reference frames since one happens to travel farther in the same amount of time.

Although, it seems to kinda make a little more immediate intuitive sense to think about it in this particular instance, much more so than with Einstein’s clocks, in terms of space dilation rather than time dilation, since I don’t think it’s necessarily immediately obvious that as a result of 1) the reference frame of an incoming muon experiencing time at a normal rate relative to the particle itself yet also 2) experiencing time around it (normal time from our reference frame measuring it) moving relatively slowly that that ultimately means it would also travel a greater distance as a result of that time dilation*, despite that being one way of describing, practically defining, the exact mechanism behind space dilation itself.

The result here is being presented in terms of distance though, despite the decay rate causing it being a product of time. We’re not looking at the time dilation of the decay rate though, we’re looking at the space dilation of the distance travelled vs what might be expected. The connections do make sense when you think about them, but logical doesn’t always mean immediately intuitive (in fact often the opposite, especially in theoretical physics) and the concept of spacetime dilation and its ramifications already gives people an infamous amount of trouble, both in terms of trying to reach a more intuitive grasp of it and in accepting in the first place




*I know that in the theory of relativity spacetime is actually conceived as a single thing, not just space + time, which is because it’s founded on the idea of the speed of light being equal in all reference frames no matter what and that is actually the natural consequence of that, hence the relationship between time dilation and space dilation itself, which is essentially a practical example of the theory being described in the video itself and also in this very comment

It's jumping to conclusions to say that "it's more than the Standard Model accounts for". In fact, the Standard Model provides room for left anti-neutrinos and right neutrinos, which are both (rather arbitrarily) excluded from it ... and it provides room for one additional force. The additional force allowed for is that which couples to baryon minus lepton number. Under it, matter would be positive charges, with right-neutrinos negative (both characteristics opposite for anti-matter). And, under it, large sources of matter - like galaxies - would provide huge charges that would attract huge clouds of right-neutrinos around them as halos. There are already tentative signals for an additional force carrier, there are also tentative signals for an "extra" variety of neutrino in Antarctica (e.g. right neutrinos) and the combination of right neutrinos and B-L force may also be the culprit behind the dark matter halos, so that this too provides yet another indication that both of these "excluded" elements are present. Examples of research dealing with this issue can be found on ArXiv. Here's one to get started Implications of right-handed neutrinos in extended standard model with scalar dark matter https://arxiv.org/abs/1707.00874

The Standard Model is -- suprise -- a model, and not a theory. Using quantum field theory, one can cook up plenty of models that extend the Standard Model, which would explain the "new Fermilab muon result" (see the recent arxiv postings in hep-ph). The challenge is to come up with a model that is "plausible", "appealing", ... by certain criteria whose explanation go beyond this comment. But one should not confuse this result with teaching us anything more fundamental about our theories: the muon g-2 is far away from exposing any fundamental aspects about our theoretical frameworks that would be incompatible with our current tools (quantum field theory and general relativity), and certainly not tackling the bigger issue which is the mathematical incompatibility between these tools -- this you cannot just fix by adding a new particle or improve the value of a certain constant.
In short, I think science journalists and communicators should pay much more attention to the distinction between "theory" and "model" these days.

Sorry, a muon is an electron in an unstable state that has absorbed enough energy that it is 207 x as massive as normal. In our Quantum universe electrons routinely absorb packets of energy or quanta. Ergo, Muons decay into an electron and lots of energy without the need to invoke the imaginary weak interaction. A muon hydrogen atom has a smaller diameter than a normal hydrogen atom. Lightning strikes can charge electrons so much that they reach a metastable state that can shrink the diameter of a hydrogen atom to that of a neutron, thus lightning creates free neutrons. So just as Rutherford suggested a century ago, there are electrons in the nucleus of the atom. See my presentations if you are curious to learn more https://www.researchgate.net/publication/350291419_The_Rutherford_Conjecture_Why_the_Taijitu_symbol_better_represents_Atomic_Physics
and the recent addition: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/350500011_How_Muons_Further_Illustrate_the_Rutherford_Conjecture

If there's one thing I've learned from reading up on the history of scientific discovery. It's that things start to get really interesting, once there is a verifiable observation that can not be explained by the current theories. There were many physicists who considered physics to be solved with Newtonian Mechanics. Then all of the "quantum physics" discoveries came along and threw a massive wrench in the works. The potentially amazing outcome of this experiment is that it might break how "solved" we consider physics to be at the moment. I.E. doing to the standard model what quantum mechanics did to Newtonian mechanics. So yes this experiment means that we "know less", but that ultimately is what is important. It gives us another path to explore, learn, and broaden or completely reinvent what we know physics to be. Science would be really boring if we already knew everything, but it is very exciting to all of the brilliant explorational minds out there when there are things yet to be learned. It is in human ingrained in human nature to go learn, discover, and explore; hence the excitement with this result. :)

I studied physics and engineering at university. Quite frankly, there is something very broken in quantum physics. It starts off well but rapidly descends into nonsense. I have no idea of how we are going to dig ourselves out of this shitshow but as it currently stands, it's a mess. So many folks are so invested in it that it's difficult for them to accept that things need a reboot. I am sick of the term "dark" being thrown about, just replace "dark" with "unknown" and it would be a great deal more honest and transparent. Not knowing and understanding we don't know is fundamental to good science. I think ther is some good work going on but there is too much "science for tourist" out there and it isn't helping anyone. It's more like sci-fi than sci-fact. Ultimately science is just a method not a thing or belief system. More transparency and honesty about not knowing would perhaps result in greater focus and help the community clarity and understand where we really are in a meaningful way. We need to seperate the wheat from the chaff so to speak and cull the nonsense.

11:23 No that's not true. Time will not flow slower for your. Time will flow the same as it did before for you - and "for you" means "from your point of view". Meaning that if you travel close to the speed of light and you look at your clock - a second will still be and tic like a normal second... What will change is what you will see if you look out the window...

If you travel close to the speed of light and look out the window you will see the clock OF OTHER PEOPLE tic slower. That doesn't mean that time for you runs slower - time for THEM runs slower from YOUR perspective.

Now on the other hand, time for them and from their point of view tics normally and if they look at you - your time now runs slower.

"how we know they pop into existence" But we don't KNOW that. We've never observed "vacuum energy". Like dark matter, we assume it's there because it makes the math work. The universe is a strange, complex place. We only have approximations describing what we've actually seen. When our observations become better than our math, we adjust our theories and/or look for something we haven't seen.

(The concentric circles model of the universe perfectly explained our beliefs and [limited] observations, at the time. We long ago stopped believing the Earth is the center of the universe, and replaced that model with a better one.)

It is worth to point out that there is some controversy about the theoretical prediction of the muon g-factor as well. The generally accepted prediction relies on existing data to estimate the effect of the hadronic vacuum polarization (a part of the "quantum foam" mentioned by Dianna). However, there are recent supercomputer calculations that predict a muon g-factor in fairly good agreement with the experimental results announced by Fermilab. Hence, part of the discussion is about the clash between these two theoretical frameworks.

Please replace the word theorized with hypothesized. A theory is not a guess as Sherlock would use the word theory. A scientific theory is an explanation of an aspect of the natural world and universe that can be repeatedly tested and verified in accordance with the scientific method, using accepted protocols of observation, measurement, and evaluation of results. Where possible, theories are tested under controlled conditions in an experiment. In circumstances not amenable to experimental testing, theories are evaluated through principles of abductive reasoning. Established scientific theories have withstood rigorous scrutiny and embody scientific knowledge.

Interesting, but the caveat at the beginning is a big one - this result needs to be repeated, and the entire experimental setup carefully scrutinized for systemic errors.

Remember that in 2011, a team of researchers at OPERA published results (with a note that even they felt that the measurements were anomalous) that indicated that they were seeing neutrinos moving faster than the speed of light. Subsequent testing and analysis revealed systemic errors in the measurements, and when they were corrected, the neutrino speeds were found to be exactly as expected.

This experiment shows strong evidence of new particles, and the existence of such particles would amazing, but this is by no means certain yet.

Not a good idea to make so many fast cuts. The natural speech breaks, pauses, including the uhs, are actually important for the listener, as it gives time to actually process what is being said and put it into one's own internal thought structures, giving room for internal critical thinking, which is crucial. Fast does not equal good. Slow down the pace of the video (not the talking, but the video), speak normally, don't cut the footage more than a few times in one video. Let the viewer see reality as it was when it happened. Less editing is better, slow is better, reality is better.

You are great at explaining complex things to people.
I have attempted my own allegorical explanation below, expanding on the more human-scale analogy that you used. A re-statement I suppose. I am passionate about science communication.
Please let me know of any misunderstanding or mistakes I have made: :)

Let's say you have a spinning top. You put the top in some apparatus to control its environment.
You know the spin rate, the mass distribution, and the strength and direction of gravity. You know of any electromagnetic properties and effects. You know the surface finishes of components and the air density, etc, allowing you to calculate resistance and damping. You control and characterise any additional forces you can. You take into account earthquakes and the spin and orbit of the earth and moon and account for every disturbance.
You calculate the reaction (to within some known precision that depends on the precision of your knowledge of the system) of the top to every force that our understanding of physics predicts that it will interact with. You calculate the error/precision that you expect to be able to measure with your equipment setup.
With this, you can calculate the state of the system, i.e. the paths, positions, orientations, velocities, accelerations, etc, over time for the duration of the experiment and the error, i.e. how precise your calculation is. The error of your system depends on many factors, like how precisely you know the initial state of the system and the strengths and directions of the forces, and on the precision of your measuring equipment. But the important fact here is that you have an estimate for the outcome of the experiment, and you know how closely your results should match that estimate.
You expect that every measured outcome will fall within the range that you calculated, and you [usually] expect that the results will have a 'normal distribution'.
That is, the likelihood of any arbitrary result sample being some particular value increases the closer that value is to your expected value, so, when you record the results of many experiments, you expect that most of the results will be close to the estimate, with fewer and fewer near the maximum and minimum of the error range.
But when you run the experiment [many times], you find that the results are unexpectedly skewed (the average of the results is 'significantly' different to the estimated value).
This is not uncommon. In some cases, experimental results can even lie outside the expected range altogether.

Usually, this sort of discrepancy is because of:
a) mistakes or equipment failure during conduction or analysis of experiment,
b) incorrect assumptions/estimates of precision of equipment and/or initial state of the system
or c) disturbances, or forces either unconsidered, or considered but incorrectly assumed insignificant.

You seek fresh eyes, take critiques on your methodology from other scientists, double check assumptions and equipment, and consider every force and effect known to man, but the discrepancy remains.

Another team attempts to recreate your experiment more carefully and with different, possibly more precise equipment in another part of the world. They account for anything you may have missed and implement tighter controls.
The error range is now tighter because of the more precise controls and measurements. If the anomalous result was caused by some environmental factor or some experimental mistake, the new results will likely disagree with the initial experiment.
The results of the second teams experiment agree with the initial experiment.

This suggests that there might be some force acting that is not known or predicted by our current knowledge of physics.

This is similar to the actual 'almost discovered' discovery, except the forces that affect the system come from phenomena less commonly understood by the layman such as the quantum vacuum foam, and the precision involved is mind boggling.

Confidence in experimental results and conclusions is complex and can depend on many factors and can be represented in several ways. Generally, more data points, less experimental error, and a lower spread (data points are closer together), the more confidence there will be in the result.
One standardized way of quantifying confidence is measured in 'sigma', with 5 sigma usually being required to announce a discovery in the field of particle physics.
A 5 sigma result that indicates some conclusion means that, if the conclusion is false, the chance of getting that or any more strongly indicative results (i.e. the chance of a false positive) is about 1 in 3.5 million.

I think (think! I am no expert) this is such a big deal because it indicates that something exists outside the current reference frame (of physics).  The "current reference frame" meaning not only things  who's existence we are fairly certain of but also an entire range of things that can possibly exist.  You have a certain number of variables each of which can interact with the others in certain ways,; the reference frame being all possible interactions.   Things that are discovered often fit reliably into the current reference frame.  When we discover something that definitely exists but our reference frame can't explain or account for it, that is a strong indication that there are variables in play that we don't know about.  Which means the entire reference frame can change.  My personal opinion is that contemporary physics (and science overall) is nearing the end of empirical reduction as the optimal logic model that serves as its core set of organizing principles (philosophy of science).  That doesn't mean empirical reduction is obsolete or in any way "wrong",  but that as a logic model it defines the limits of what can be known and these limits have been put to the test over the last several decades.  As far as what logic model or philosophy of science could expand the range of what can be known, I would point squarely at phenomenology as per Husserl.

New measurement of muon G-2 is a remarkable achievement. However "new physics which we don't know" is not the only possibility. Another one is that there is an old physics which we don't know: low-energy QCD (and in fact any non-perturbative quantum field theory). QCD contributions are negligible at the energy scale of the electron mass, that's why the theoretical prediction of electron G-2 is in such a nice agreement with experiments. On the other hand muon is ~ 200x more massive, and QCD corrections (loosely speaking bumps from virtual protons, pions, and other strongly interacting particles) are more important. And we can't compute those from the first principles. So disagreement between the theory and experiment is not that surprising.

"So you brought us in here to tell us, after all this, that there's more we don't know?"
Yes, that's why she's excited. Scientists get giddy when there's suddenly a whole new part of the map to explore, especially when it's in a spot that we thought we had filled in pretty well! That sort of thing means a whole slew of new questions that can be asked, and questions are the heart of each step in learning new things.

"The newest discovery in physics: we might know less than we thought?!"
Incorrect! We now know more than we did before, because everything we knew before is still true, but we also now know that there may be something we didn't know about those things we knew. Knowing that we don't know something is knowing more than not knowing it at all! We've learned that the boundaries of our precision have hidden something from us that has been there inside of the current model but has not yet been identified! That's something we know that we didn't know before at all. We know more... we just don't know what it is yet. ;)

4.2 sigma: I think, she fell for the Bayes-paradox.
The "1 in 40,000" ist the chance that a given experiment measures random fluctuations with 4.2 sigma.
This does not say anything about the chance that a result of 4.2 sigma is actually correct.
It's the same effect as with positive covid-test, that we should all know by now :-)

my take on explaining the G-2 experiment and its implications in an extremely condensed form:

So there's a value in physics associated with each particle that's called the G-factor. The good thing is that this value can be measured from an experiment AND calculated from the theory. Another interesting property of G-factor is that G-factor of one type of particle depends on all other possible particles and interactions in the theory. And G-factor for an electron was calculated a long time ago and its theoretical estimation matches experimental one with extreme precision. However, it can also be calculated for a different type of particle, the muon, and the experiment has shown that the value is ever so slightly different from theory. Since its theoretical value is based on all other particles in the theory, it means that either the theory is wrong (unlikely) or that there's some particles in it that we don't know of(more likely).

In regards to your Muon explanation. You have cosmic rays coming through our atmosphere and on the high side where the atmosphere is thinner at the top of the Mountain where you have less muons. Then at the base of the Mountain you have more muons. You also have thicker atmosphere giving more particles to interact with the cosmic rays in order to produce more muons. You could consider this from a point of view of the northern lights. How often have the citizens of Florida commented about they saw the northern lights? And yet citizens of Alaska see them on a very regular basis. Why is this? The earth is a giant magnet and so the cosmic rays, drawn by that magnetic force, which tend to rain down on the North Pole. Now as that it is these cosmic rays that create the northern lights the people living further north tend to see them regularity. As for those further south, who’s view is blocked by the curvature of the earth, never see them. We know that cosmic rays coming from all directions so why don’t Floridians see the aurora borealis being generated in the atmosphere above them? The answer is not a high enough concentration of cosmic rays hitting the atmosphere. That’s showing that the magnetic energy surrounding the earth can affect cosmic rays but it doesn’t prove anything about altering time based on speed. So for those cosmic raise that rain down and are not affected by the magnetic field of the earth they would have the same effect of hitting a more dense atmosphere at a lower elevation as a higher concentration of cosmic rays hitting a less dense atmosphere at a higher elevation, more interaction. Again no proof of time distortion.

I calculated that you would only weigh less then .1 kilograms more if you had muons instead of electrons. The way I calculated this was simple (mass of an electron*207+mass of a proton)/(mass of an electron*207+mass of a proton). Now, while protons and neutrons do vary in weight, and then also slightly differ more depending on what atom they are in, it should be fine for estimation purposes. Anyway, plugging this in yielded 1.7*10^-3 which makes sense considering our initial values were about 10^4 apart. Then multiplying this by the average humans mass in kilograms gives us .108Kg. The reason I said less then 1Kg though, is because this calculation assumes that there are only protons and electrons, and that there are an equal number of each. Of course, neutrons exist, so that would drive the numbers further down.
Mind you, I could have easily made a mistake in my own calculations.

I would compare this to mercury's abnormal precession. There was pretty good theory of how plantes should move - Newtonian gravity. And virtually every experiment confirmed it. Mercury should have precessed due to other planets but in 1859 it was noted it's precession is slightly bigger than expected. It meant either the measurements were wrong or Newton's theory was. Probably best tested to the day. In 1915 Einstein proposed general relativity, which re(de)fined gravity... And explained the experimental result.

That's why we think this muon result is indication of incomplete theory and new physics. Even if it's best tested theory, it seems physical observation is no fluke. Previously it meant a jump from Newton to Einstein. In years 1687 theory, 1859 experiment that broke it, 1915 new theory.

Both muons and positrons showed up in early cloud chamber experiments where they could track the path of particles deflected by the magnetic field.  The missing mass in fission events led to the hypothesis of the neutrino (and its eventual discovery).  The alternate hypothesis was that the universe did not conserve energy, and nobody liked that idea.  Finally, the original neutrino detection experiments led to results lower than theory predicted, which led to the realization that neutrinos did have mass (just a wee bit), which invalidated the standard model at the time.  (Which again, nobody was happy about, but they got over it.)  Thus science is a constant cycle of measurement discrepancy, updated theories, new experiments.
